title: How to Change the Heating Element in a Dryer

steps.title: Unplug the dryer.
steps.content: Unplug the dryer. Make sure there's no power going to your dryer while you're working.

steps.title: Take off dryer exhaust hose and remove the back panel.
steps.content: Take off dryer exhaust hose and remove the back panel. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Look at the back of the dryer.
steps.content: Look at the back of the dryer. On the right side, you'll see a long metal (probably gray) housing. The Element is inside. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Unscrew the black sensor on top, and unscrew the black sensor on the bottom.
steps.content: Unscrew the black sensor on top, and unscrew the black sensor on the bottom. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Unhook the two wires just below the bottom sensor.
steps.content: Unhook the two wires just below the bottom sensor. (These two sensors could be your problem (in 50% of the cases, it is). Also, there is a heating fuse to your left, under the larger casing on the left. It is about an inch long, and has two wires attached. This can also be your problem. One screw holds it in. If in doubt, take all these to the appliance store, and they'll test them with a voltmeter.) Test the heating element with a multimeter by setting it to read continuity. Touch the 2 leads of the heating element with the multimeter. If there isn't any continuity, then you need to replace the element.

steps.title: Gently lift up on the whole gray casing.
steps.content: Gently lift up on the whole gray casing. It should easily come loose. If not, lift a little harder and pull the bottom toward you. There may be a screw and small bracket at the top that needs to be removed. There are some hooks on the bottom that will come loose.

steps.title: Turn it upside down; you'll see one screw holding the element in.
steps.content: Turn it upside down; you'll see one screw holding the element in. Take out the screw, and carefully pull out the element, which is a coil that heats up, on some metal housing. Examine the coil for breaks. If you have a voltmeter, test the element. Also test the Sensors. This will tell you what's broken.

steps.title: Install the new element in the reverse of the above.
steps.content: Install the new element in the reverse of the above. Replace the element, replace all the sensors and the back panel, as well as the exhaust hose. When done, try it out! [4] X Research source
